ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Anobha Gurung
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Anobha Gurung
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  She was very responsive and helpful.

Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Anobha was amazing - always very helpful and responsive. She managed to spend time with everyone who would go to her office hours; she quickly responded to e-mails and always offered her help and assistance. I wouldn't be able to complete the assignments without Anobha's help. She is the best TA I've had at F&ES.
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Anobha Gurung
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Anobha Gurung
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  She had problems interpreting the assignments as we did. However, she was wonderful and very helpful on going through the ArcMap tools.
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Anobha was excellent!
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Anobha
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Minimal interaction with teaching fellow.
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  anobha
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Anobha Gurung
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Anobha Gurung is very nice and very helpful in GIS.
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Wonderful! Very kind and helpful
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  was amazing!!!

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The assignments were really hard, but as a result we learned a lot. I think it was basically impossible to figure them out without consulting with peers, or the Teaching Assistant. While working in the computer lab, I felt that the TA sometimes rushed through explanations and I felt a bit uncomfortable asking my very basic questions. Perhaps this is because she had so many students asking her questions at the same time.It wasn't always easy to follow along during the lecture, but things made more sense when working on the assignments in a more hands-on manner.
14. I have taken both the raster and vector classes offered at F&ES, and found them to be challenging but extremely useful for my work both in and out of the classroom.
N/A
Great course, I completely recommend!
One of the best courses at FES.
Fantastic introduction to GIS.
Dana is the best! We actually learn how to do analysis in GIS. It is awesome!
When it come to explaining a complex and seemingly theoretical concept in a simple and accessible manner I have met no one better than Professor Tomlin.

I was very surprised and disappointed by how arbitrary the homework assignments were. I don't plan to be a GIS wizard - I just wanted to familiarize myself with the software and gain a basic toolset for work that I will need to tackle in the future. I was also hoping to gain a sense for how GIS would be used in other ways by people in my field. With the arbitrary homework assignments, I really didn't get exposure to other viable projects that might be done by my colleagues. It also made it very difficult to invest myself in the work. I understand that the instructor gave the option to come up with my own homework assignment, but unless I have a problem on my mind and ready to go, that can be a lot of work. And I already don't have enough time as it is.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Dana's ability to transfer knowledge from his incredibly powerful brain to mine, which operates in a totally different way, is really impressive.
I feel like I learned a lot, and I feel comfortable using a number of tools. I'm likely to take another GIS course in the fall. It was fun to have a big puzzle to solve every week.

This class challenges students to think about spatial analysis and use of technology in a way that hasn't been offered in my other classes. Students are encouraged to work together, be creative, and think through a problem as they learn new tools - which is highly applicable to our professional work. The instructor is responsive to student questions and encourages discussion.
The class teaches applicable, real-life concepts that are very helpful for job search; amazing instructor
It teaches you how to think through a worm eye perspective
It covered a range of tools in raster GIS.
Professor Tomlin is a real asset. His concern for student's learning and well-being is terrific.
Dana is a great Professor. Class was generally engaging.

Professor Tomlin somehow finds a way to explain the technical tools with real-life stories and situations, in a context we can understand. Behind having technical mastery of the concepts, he also is simply a good teacher, a combination which is rare at this school.

Overall, I thought that this course was excellent. I get the sense that I learned much more in this class than one would typically learn in an introductory raster GIS class. Dana Tomlin is clearly a GIS expert and also clearly invests a lot of time and thought into communicating the material in a way that maximizes student learning. He is also extremely responsive to student inquiries. He is a knowledgeable and devoted teacher.
Dana's effective and refined teaching style& enthusiasm for subject. It is probably the best course I have ever taken.
Dana is incredibly knowledgeable and incredibly attentive to the emails, requests, and considerations of the students.
The instructor and assignments challenge you to think in difficult but ultimately rewarding ways.
The way lectures and homeworks built and strengthened knowledge throughout the course of the semester was really excellent.

Dana let us work on google projects if we wanted instead of doing the homework- this gave us the space to pitch projects to google. several of us are going out to google now to present these projects!
Learning whats possible
The homework will teach you a lot about how GIS works.

Although it made the course all the more challenging, I loved that we were expected to use the ArcMap tools in different ways from what would be expected. I also appreciated the professor's ability to explain concepts in multiple ways so that we could gain a better understanding of how to approach the program and our assignments.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: We used abstract examples instead of relevant and applied scenarios. Instead of looking for clowns in cities, it would have been helpful to find suitable areas for forest growth, corn production, or a wild life reserve.Also: The course was about understanding how to "think GIS" instead of how to successfully present something in GIS. Practical things like how to import a map into ArcGIS were left out.We mostly focused on a few tools and many tools were not addressed at all.
none

Following along with the lecture was sometimes challenging, and I was a bit intimidated to ask questions in class (given the size of the class and the fact that I often felt my peers had a better handle on things than me). Also, it was sometimes a bit disheartening to really get stuck on an assignment and to not be able to move forward at all without help from peers or the TA (some of whom were able to figure it out on their own). It was also a little disappointing for the final assignment of the class to be so difficult! I would have liked to end on a high note...
N/A
The group projects this semester were a bit challenged. I'm not sure where they went off track.
The workload got to be just too heavy. I was very burned out on GIS from spring break onwards.

The time commitment is extraordinary. I realize this is necessary for such a technical class, but just making the statement so that the search can continue for anything to lessen the workload.It should be noted that when students complained near the end of the semester, Professor Tomlin changed the final project to be less work.

Although the pace was fast and the workload was quite heavy, I did not find it to be problematic until the end of the semester, when the group work increased and the challenges became primarily logistical, as opposed to conceptual. The lastcouple of assignments didn't seem to be as well thought out or deliberate as all the others. In future years, I would suggest introducing model builder earlier, so that students get more practice with it throughout the semester.
None. I liked the brain teasers.

I found it hard, at the end of the semester, to know what to focus on. We tailored our presentation to something that would appeal to the class, as we were told that it would be graded by our classmates; we then found out that there would be no grading by the class (and no extra points for a good presentation, even though Dana mentioned there was the possibility of such).The assignments themselves were also sometimes tricky to figure out exactly what the end goal was- I do not mean in terms of how to solve the assignments, but sometimes it felt like we had to do it the particular way that Dana wanted us to do it.I'd also have liked a focus on using external data that one might look for and find in a real-world project setting (e.g., searching for datasets online instead of being provided them, then figuring out how to use them).
Very little indeed.
It would be nice to have more detailed feedback on the individual homework printouts.
the teaching fellow hours did not jive with me schedule. evenings are better.
None - professor is highly flexible.

The homework TAKES TOO LONG! If there is to be 2 hours of homework for every 1 hour of class, this class' homework should take 6 hours apiece. This means that homework for this class takes about 10 hours too long on average. My studies for other classes suffered because of the amount of effort required to get even a so-so grade in this class.
Homework assignments

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There wasn't a discussion/lab section, but that's not a bad idea. A structured chance for people to ask their questions and share their progress on the homework assignment.
N/A
Very effective - the class is structured very well and it's organized in a way that helps learn the concepts in a logical fashion
n/a
N/A. Assignments were extremely relevant and a useful learning tool.
Interdependent

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: i didn't really interact with her.
N/A
She was well organized and very helpful. Had a good amount of knowledge in the subject matter.
Anobha was very helpful during office hours. She was always willing to answer questions and to work through challenges with students.

Instructor: Anobha Gurung  She was very nice and understands the concepts very well.Since so many people were asking her questions during the Office Hours, I sometimes felt she was responding in a slightly annoyed/exasperated manner. This made me uncomfortable to ask very basic questions.Also, sometimes I think she found it easier to click through some steps (on my computer) herself, rather than instructing me on what steps to do. If she could either do this slowly and explain as she's going, or instruct me as I click, I think that would be more beneficial to students' learning.In-person responses to questions were more helpful than email responses.

Instructor: Anobha Gurung  The teaching assistant was extremely helpful in answering student questions during office hours and through e-mail. However, there was often a line of students waiting to ask her questions about the homework assignments, and it was difficult to maximize our time. It would be helpful in the future to have more than one teaching assistant for this course.
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  I did not utilize the TA this semester though I heard from classmates that she was very helpful.
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Anobha was great!
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Anobha was often helpful, but also often seemed to be on the same page as the rest of the students, struggling to figure out the assignment along with us.
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  Minimal interaction. TF seemed very accessible and helpful.
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  She as helpful the one time I interacted with her, but I had classes most of the time she was available.
Instructor: Anobha Gurung  She was patient and helpful if you showed up to her office hours. I didn't receive e-mail responses, though.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: My course of study relates to land use change and management policies, so the analytical and presentation skills that I learned in this class will be integral to future work and career paths.
It didn't initially - but I am glad I took it, GIS is a great skill to have

GIS is used in a multitude of different disciplines. Therefore, while it does help with my ecological studies, I have no doubt it would also be useful in other fields. In addition, the course taught skills other than those strictly related to GIS, such as systematic thinking.
This course is integral to my program.
This class is vital to any land management program, among many others.

I took this course as a skills-building complement to other research and theory courses. I have enjoyed interspersing these practical, hands-on classes with other more theoretical and discussion-based classes during my time at Yale.

GIS analysis and application will most likely be a large portion of my work and research well into my career, so this course not only fits into my overall program, but was necessary. It's also incredibly interesting and fun to do!

Not directly relevant but nonetheless useful. Geospatial analysis is one of several very powerful and increasingly available tools that can inform policymaking. Understanding these tools is crucial to their sound use.
GIS is a prerequisite for environmental management
I use raster analysis heavily for my research.
Teaches a practical skill
Mapping will be helpful in any outdoor profession.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: because i heard dana was great.

When we entered FES, I remember the career folks told us that GIS is the top skill environmental employers are looking for these days. I also knew I wanted to develop a skill which I could apply to future work. I also like that GIS skills create the potential to work on discrete/tangible projects, which seems more concrete than other policy work (which can feel abstract).
I did not have a background in mapping or GIS programming, and wanted to develop these skills early in my academic work at F&ES.
I wanted to gain practical skills in something that was relevant to my interests.
To learn how to use GIS and have a practical skill and working knowledge of the program
To learn GIS skills
This will be a very useful skill set in my career.
I think GIS is a good skill to have, and useful to be familiar with.

I almost did not take this course because I thought I could learn GIS anytime, anywhere after Yale, even on the job. However, this class was more than just about technical skills.... It was about the bigger concepts, how to frame problems, how to think about multiple issues, and most importantly, about whyyou are doing things, from the narrow view of using specific functions all the way up to the broad scope of analyzing what motivates you to get things done.

I wanted to gain a basic understanding of the capabilities of GIS and some basic spatial analysis skills that I could apply to my research and future work. I do feel that I gained a strong foundation in raster GIS and will certainly use the skills I gained going forward.
See above. I need knowledge of GIS for my research, I really enjoy it, and I like Dana as a professor.
I think knowing how to use GIS isa valuable skill.

The ability to understand, process and interpret vast quantities of data, including spatial data, will be increasingly useful in the coming years as computing power and information availability increase. The course was intended to help me understand spatial thinking and the possibilities that arise from it.
To run hydrologic models better.
GIS skills
Interest.
I think the program is an important thing to have at least a working knowledge of regardless of what type of environmental field you work in.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: No. Really not.
yes, and then exceeded.

Kind of. I feel like I have some competencies, but I don't really feel like I have a solid handle on all of the material presented in the course. I am not really sure how I would describe my level of comfort/familiarity with GIS on my resume or in a job interview.
Exceeded expectations.
Definitely. Even though I haven't necessarily mastered the information I feel very comfortable with the program and with the concept of visual mapping.
Yes, very much so
yes!
Yes
Yes
Yes, absolutely.
Exceeded.
Yes, I gained far more skills than I anticipated in a one semester, introductory course.
Definitely.
Exceeded my expectations.
Yes. I feel confident in my ability to use GIS.
Yes. Raster processing trains a particular and powerful form of spatial thinking. Very rewarding.
Can confidently say that I am now proficient in GIS.
Far exceed! Taking this and remote sensing was really helpful (at the same time) in terms of me thinking in pixels. I have a good intuitive feel for math on maps now.
YEs
Yes.
Yes, exceeded my expectations in that I feel comfortable with the program, did not meet them in that I know there's much more for me to learn.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Exchange about different ways of problem solving.
for a class where there may be multiple ways to look at a problem, group work was incredibly valuable because it allowed us to discuss the merits of each of a variety of approaches.

Mostly advantages! Exchange of ideas and different ways of approaching problems. Also the camaraderie of struggling with others! I really liked working with the people I did work with, but I can imagine that there are some people I might find more challenging to work with.

Although it was sometimes difficult to coordinate shared time in the computer lab, I found it necessary to bounce ideas off of each other as we figured out how to bring tools together to solve a problem. Many of the groups organized themselves around the teaching assistant office hours, although the timing was not always convenient.
With weekly assignments it would sometimes be hard to coordinate schedules, but I enjoyed getting to know other students.
Group work helped me better understand the concepts and learn how to use the program
It is great to know how other folks do the same thing you do differently.
Like with most group work, the advantages of working together is learning from others, while the disadvantage is often uneven distribution of work.
These projects take a lot of time each week and it is very difficult to find that kind of time to work as a group.That said, I really enjoyed the group work!
The complexities of ArcGIS are compounded by the complexities of working with others in ArcGIS. Necessary life skills.

The group work was the most frustrating aspect of the course for me. Because the assignments are quite time-intensive (often necessitating 10-15 hours of work in a week for high-quality work), simply coordinating scheduling with group members was a real challenge. Moreover, the expectations and rules were generally not adequately laid out or consistently applied with the group work. I much preferred--and feel I got more out of--the assignments on which I worked alone.
I like working with others with this kind of work - I think it allows for enlightenment and exploration, as well as camaraderie when it can be frustrating.
Good: Bouncing ideas off each other, talking things out.No real bad parts.
The expectations of group work deliverables were vaguely defined.
We all learned fro each other and it was exciting. But sometimes hard, because not all students understand and learn the same way.
Same as always
Learned different GIS techniques from my peers; ended up bearing a heavier workload and scheduling meeting times was difficult.

It was really important to have someone to bounce ideas off of for certain assignments. The homeworks required thinking about the tools in many different ways. The program itself can be frustrating and arranging schedules to work together for extended and frustrating periods of time is difficult.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: remember that dana's too fair to want you to devote your entire life to this class. it's okay to do other people's homework too.

Be aware that this course is a lot of work, so I would make sure you plan to have enough time in your schedule to really be able to spend time on this class. Definitely work with a partner when permitted. Dana is great about responding to questions over email, so don't hesitate to write to him with problems you encounter.

This is one of the best courses that I've taken so far! The work load is heavy but it is also a crucial part of learning GIS, so students should make sure that they are able to devote the time every week that is needed to succeed.
Be aware that weekly assignments take a significant amount of time and can get extremely frustrating, but I definitely felt like it was time well spent.
Take it! The work and hours are totally worth it!
Take it!
Take it!
Be aware that it's a *lot* of work.
Be ready for a lot of time, but it is totally worth it. This is one of the best classes at this school and will make you a better student.

You will get out of this course what you put in. If you are willing and able to devote 10-to-15 hours a week to this course, you will progress quite quickly. If, on the other hand, you have many other commitments and are taking other courses with heavy workloads, you will probably struggle to keep up and will not get as much out of the course as you could.If you do take the course, take advantage of Dana's offers to communicate via email and in person. These conversations will help you understand the assignments and grasp the course concepts.
Definitely take the course, it will prove useful.
It is a lot of work; but it is totally worth it. Dana is an amazing teacher.
Do the work. Allow enough time for it. Ask questions. Think like a worm.
Take it! and Take vector! and take remote sensing! they all compliment each other so well.
DON'T TAKE ANY OTHER DIFFICULT CLASSES. THIS CLASS WILL TAKE OVER YOUR LIFE.
Limit the amount of time you give to each assignment and always look for opportunities to improve your grade; re-doing the assignment helps to understand the program more clearly.
